title: Are My Emails Making Me Look Less Serious at Work?
summary: This article talks about how the way we write emails can affect how people see us at work. It explains that using too many exclamation marks, smiley faces, or saying sorry too much might make others think we are not very serious or confident. Experts say that women often use more exclamation marks than men because they worry about being judged. Emojis can also be tricky because different people might understand them in different ways. The article gives tips from coaches on how to write emails that show we are friendly but also professional. It helps us think about our email habits to make sure we are taken seriously and have better chances at work.

background_read: This article is about email communication in the workplace. It explains that small things like punctuation and emojis can change how others see us. For example, using too many exclamation marks or smiley faces might make us seem less confident or professional. Experts share why this happens, especially for women who might face more judgment. The article gives simple advice on writing emails that are friendly but also show we are serious about our work. It helps kids understand why being careful with words is important in jobs.
Article_Structure: WHO: The article features experts like careers coach Hannah Salton and etiquette coach William Hanson, and discusses people who write emails at work.
WHAT: It explains how using too many exclamation marks, apologies, and emojis in emails can make someone seem less serious or confident, affecting how they are perceived and promoted.
WHERE: This happens in workplace settings where people communicate through emails.
WHY: To raise awareness about email habits and provide tips for writing more professional emails to be taken seriously at work.

perspectives.description: Coaches explain that excessive friendliness in emails, like overusing exclamation marks or emojis, can undermine credibility and professionalism.
